-COVID-19 tests are available at many major hospitals in Greece. Testing is paid by the individual being tested.  The cost for COVID-19 PCR tests is capped at 47 euros, and for rapid antigen tests at 10 euros, though additional charges may apply for testing at home or other circumstances.  Patients needing COVID-19 tests or exhibiting possible symptoms may contact the COVID-19 hotline at 1135 for guidance on testing and referral for medical care.  Travelers are recommended to contact testing centers in advance for appointments and not expect to be able to test and receive PCR results the day of travel.  -Test results may be delivered by e-mail or in hard copy provided in person; consult with the testing facility regarding the method results are communicated for your specific circumstance.  -The Greek National Tourism Organization has published a list of diagnostic testing sites to take a PCR or Antigen (rapid) test via the GreeceHealthFirst.gr website.  They have also included a map of COVID-19 diagnostic testing locations in the Visit Greece app, which is available for download via Google Play or the App Store.  The U.S. Embassy does not endorse any particular diagnostic testing sites, and recommends that travelers contact sites in advance to make appointments and confirm necessary details.  -For information on limited humanitarian exemptions to the COVID-19 testing requirement for U.S. entry, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html.  If you review the information at the preceding link and believe you qualify for a humanitarian exemption despite widespread availability of testing in Greece, use the contact information at the bottom of this page to make your request.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220419052312/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

-If you test positive for COVID-19 while in Greece you must self-isolate for 5 days from the date of the positive test result. You may leave self-isolation after 5 days if you are no longer experiencing symptoms, otherwise you should continue to self-isolate.  -If you have been in close contact with someone who has tested positive and have received your booster, you are not obliged to self-isolate but must take a PCR or rapid test on day 5 of the exposure. If you are unvaccinated or are vaccinated but have not received your booster, you must take a PCR or rapid test and self-isolate for 5 days.  -The above guidance may not apply in the case of variants of special interest. These cases will be assessed by the EMEA (Greek health authority) and appropriate instructions will be given.  -Depending on the circumstances, you may be able to self-isolate in your current accommodation, or Greek authorities will ask you to self-isolate in a state provided quarantine hotel. The expense of the accommodation in quarantine hotels is covered by the Greek state. Local authorities will be able to offer further advice on self-isolation requirements.  -If you do not self-isolate or quarantine when required you may be fined by the Hellenic Police. The fine could be as much as â¬5000. You should comply with any requirement to self-isolate or quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220419054447/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

-Masks Still Required; Other Restrictions Still in Effect:    Greek authorities continue to enforce other restrictions to prevent the spread of COVID-19, including restrictions on certain business and entertainment operations, restrictions on the size of gatherings, and capacity limitations for public transport and businesses. As of December 24th at 6:00am masks are mandatory in all indoor spaces. As of March 5th, Greece will no longer require masks to be worn when outdoors, though masks are recommended in crowded, poorly ventilated areas and by the unvaccinated. Double mask or high protection-type (such as an N95) mask is required in supermarkets and on public transportation.  Additional information is available in English at travel.gov.gr and in Greek at the Civil Protection website and the Greek governmentâs COVID-19 Measures website.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220419052312/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

-Use of a protective mask in all indoor areas including workplaces with the exception of those working in a private space without the presence of any other person. The obligation to use a mask excludes: a) persons for whom the use of a mask is not indicated for medical reasons proven by the appropriate documents, such as due to respiratory problems and b) children under the age of four (4) years. 2. Keeping distances of one and a half (1.5) meters between individuals [one (1) person per 2 sq.m.] indoors and outdoors, either pure for fully vaccinated and sick during the last trimester or mixed, where not provided larger area per person in the individual forecasts hereof. 3. Placement / use of an alcoholic solution with a content of more than seventy percent (70%) for hand antiseptic. 4. Obligation to post in a document or digital way in a visible place of the rules of operation of shops and businesses, including the maximum number of people allowed to be inside the space. 5. Ventilation of the premises in a natural or artificial way in application of the sub-elements.  -Natural persons who do not comply with the obligation to use a mask, the rules of keeping distance, as well as the other rules of article 1, are imposed for each violation, with a reasoned act of the competent authority, if there is no more specific provision in par. 1, an administrative fine of three hundred (300) euros.  -This is valid from Monday, April 18, 2022 at 06:00 until Sunday, May 1, 2022 at 06:00.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220419052806/https://covid19.gov.gr/leitourgia-dikastirion-ektakta-metra-prostasias-tis-dimosias-ygeias-apo-ton-kindyno-peraitero-diasporas-tou-koronoiou-sars-cov2-sto-synolo-tis-epikrateias-gia-to-diastima-gia-to-diastima-apo-t/

Conditions for entry into Greenland:  -To be permitted to enter Greenland, you must either be fully vaccinated, a resident in Greenland or relocating to Greenland.  -There is no longer a requirement to present a negative PCR test upon entry into Greenland.    Requirements to enter Greenland by air or sea:  People who are 12 years old or older must be able to document one of the following things in order to enter Greenland by air or sea:  -If you are a resident in Greenland, you must document this with a certificate of residence or something else that documents your residency. You can download your certificate of residence at sullissivik.gl.  -If you are about to move to Greenland, you must be able to document that you have a job or a home in Greenland. For example, you can use a rental contract, a contract of employment or a letter from your coming employer as proof.  -If you are not a resident of Greenland you must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 and able to provide documentation proving this.  -You are considered fully vaccinated 14 days after you have completed a full vaccination programme, e.g. two doses of Pfizer or Moderna or one dose of Johnson&Johnson. There is currently no upper limit as to how long a person is considered fully vaccinated. There is no requirement for a booster vaccination to be considered fully vaccinated. Only vaccines approved by EMA are accepted.  -Furthermore, you must live up to the rules on use of face masks during travel to Greenland.  Last updated Wednesday 2. march  https://web.archive.org/web/20220411234343/https://corona.nun.gl/en/travel/conditions-for-entry-into-greenland/

Good advice for people at a higher risk:  -In general, if you are someone who is at a higher risk, you can continue to do the things you did before the COVID-19 pandemic, e.g. go to work, participate in leisure activities and take care of your grandchildren.  -If before the COVID-19 pandemic, you had to follow special precautions in your daily life to avoid being infected with an infectious disease, e.g. you have a special condition and are immunocompromised, you should continue to follow those precautions.    The National Board of Health in Greenland (âLandslÃ¦geembedetâ) recommends the following for persons who are at a higher risk:  -Get re-vaccinated  -Follow the recommendations from the Office of the Medical Director of Health and ask others to be mindful  -Avoid large events and gatherings of people where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider using a face mask in public spaces where you canât keep a distance to other people  -Consider talking with your workplace about how to ensure that you can go to work safely    The older you are â the more and more serious chronic diseases have â the more attention you need to pay to following the recommendations. You must naturally take your quality of life into consideration, when you place limits on your life.  *Risk groups and highly vulnerable people  Last updated Friday 4. february  https://web.archive.org/web/20220412002453/https://corona.nun.gl/en/information-about-covid-19/

In order to adapt as much as possible to the new conditions, employers are advised to organize, wherever possible, work from home or work in shifts, in order to avoid interfering with workers. For the protection of one's own, but also the health of others, it is recommended that all business trips be postponed and that meetings be held online. Jobs related to the health care system also have specially prescribed measures that employees must adhere to so that the system itself is not overloaded.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403224542/https://koronavirus.hr/o-poslu/46

Professional artistic performances, cultural programs and events attended only by persons (visitors, performers and staff) holding an EU digital COVID certificate of vaccination, testing and / or recovery from COVID-19 are exempt from all restrictions of this recommendation - including the obligation to wear masks, physical distances, number of persons present, etc. Also, if all contractors have an EU digital COVID certificate, they are exempt from all anti-epidemic measures.    It is mandatory to use a face mask indoors and when it is not possible to maintain a physical distance of at least 1.5 m outdoors. The obligation to use the mask does not apply to visitors during the consumption of food and beverages, nor to contractors during the performance.    It is obligatory to adhere to the measure of physical distancing which avoids close personal contact at a distance of at least 1.5 meters outdoors and 2 meters indoors. It is not necessary for people living in a joint household to maintain the prescribed distance. The distance between the visitor and the performer on stage must be at least 4 meters.     The physical distance between visitors during the program, the organizer must provide seats 1.5 meters apart  Exceptionally, when holding performances, cultural programs and low-risk events, the physical distance between visitors from 1 seat is allowed, with the obligatory wearing of masks during the program. The restriction does not apply to visitors living in the same household. Low-risk programs are programs with exclusively seating places that do not involve interaction with the audience and active engagement of the audience such as singing.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403225317/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-svakodnevnom-zivotu/preporuke-za-sprjecavanje-zaraze-covid-19-tijekom-odrzavanja-profesionalnih-umjetnickih-izvedbi-kulturnih-programa-i-manifestacija/740

No policy change.  A negative viral test result: PCR not older than 72 hours or rapid antigen test (list of acceptable antigen tests) not older than 48 hours (counting from the time of taking the test to arriving at the border crossing point).  A certificate showing they have received two doses of vaccine used in the EU Member States or vaccines approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since receiving the second dose of the vaccine, or a certificate showing they have received a single doze of the vaccine if the vaccine is administered in a single doze not older than 270 days, provided that 14 days have passed since the single doze, or a certificate that they have received the booster doze of the vaccine.  A certificate showing that they have recovered from COVID-19 and have received one dose of vaccine used in EU Member States or a vaccine approved by the World Health Organization for emergency use, provided that 14 days have passed since they received the single dose within eight months from contracting the disease, provided that the vaccine was administered less than 270 days from their arrival at the border crossing point.  A positive PCR test result or rapid antigen test result, confirming that the holder recovered from the SARS-CoV-2 virus infection, which was performed in the previous 180 days, and which is older than 11 days from the date of arrival at the border crossing point, or a medical certificate of recovery.  Perform PCR testing or rapid antigen testing immediately upon arrival to Croatia (at the travelerâs own expense), with the obligation to stay in self-isolation until receiving a negative test result. If testing cannot be performed, travelers must self-isolate for a period of 10 days.  Travelers can facilitate faster processing at the Croatian border by completing the Enter Croatia web form and uploading their information and attachments ahead of their arrival.  Tourists are also required to show the proof of booked or paid accommodation or ownership of a home or a vessel when entering Croatia.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
No evidence of income support.
No evidence of debt/contract relief.
Updates and recommendations consistently posted online.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403232111/https://www.koronavirus.hr/

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Croatia? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within one calendar day? Yes  A test can be arranged at the following locations:?COVID-19 Testing Locations in Croatia.  The cost of a local test (rapid antigen test or a PCR test) ranges from $40 to $150 or more, depending upon the location, and the result can be expected between 1-48 hours depending upon the type of the test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
Mobile app is available for contact tracing but no evidence of 'on-the-ground' contact tracing. I believe previous coding has relied on the mobile app availability as evidence of contact tracing.

Wearing protective masks is mandatory?in all closed spaces throughout?the country. Masks are also mandatory in open spaces where a physical distance of at least 1.5 meters cannot be maintained.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Has the government of Croatia approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use? Yes  Are vaccines available in Croatia for U.S. citizens to receive? Yes  Which vaccines are available in Croatia? PfizerâBioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson.  According to the Croatian Institute for Public Health, foreigners with temporary or permanent residency in Croatia can register for the COVID-19 vaccine through their local healthcare provider.  If you have an OIB (Croatian Personal Identification Number) and a local health insurance plan, you may visit https://cijepise.zdravlje.hr/ to register to get vaccinated.  If you do not have a local health insurance plan, you may visit the following Croatian Institute of Public Health website for the contact details of the county public health institutes to register by phone.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403071447/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Updated March 17: New measures have been announced to address the elderly population, which is also the most vulnerable. Follow these pages, we will publish them as soon as they are official.    The most effective general prevention measures:  frequent hand hygiene with products containing 70% alcohol: rub your hands if your hands are invisibly dirty or wash with soap and water if your hands are dirty for about 20 seconds  avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth  maintain air hygiene by coughing or sneezing into a bent elbow or tissue and then immediately throw the tissue in the trash can with a lid  wearing a medical mask is mandatory if you have respiratory symptoms  after removing the mask from the face it is mandatory to carry out hand hygiene  maintaining a distance in social contact between persons of at least 1 meter if the person has any of the respiratory symptoms  maintain the hygiene of your living space by periodically wiping surfaces that are frequently touched with your hands with a surface disinfectant     https://web.archive.org/web/20220403232847/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-prevenciji/vazne-upute-za-starije-osobe-i-kronicne-bolesnike/51

the government is providing several significant subsidies:    parents received a family tax refund. In February 2022, parents raising a child were reimbursed for their income tax paid in 2021 up to the tax level of the average wage.  Retirees received a larger-than-ever pension premium  of HUF 80,000 in November and received a full refund  of their 13-month pension  in February 2022 .  Wage increases will continue: from January 2022 , the minimum wage will be HUF 200,000, the guaranteed minimum wage will be HUF 260,000,  thus the minimum wage will be higher from 2022 onwards.  Young people under the age of  25 will not have to pay income tax  from January 2022.  The credit moratorium was extended until June 30, 2022. Those who are expecting and raising a child, retirees, public employees can continue to take advantage of the opportunity, as can businesses and individuals whose incomes have fallen significantly from the previous year.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220411190956/https://koronavirus.gov.hu/aktualis

Outside of this, the officially regulated price for a PCR test is 19,500 HUF, with antigen tests being offered from 8,500 to 15,000 HUF. Some facilities offer express results for an additional fee.  https://archive.ph/iy45F

From 1st April 2022, If you have symptoms of COVID-19 you should self-isolate until 48 hours after your symptoms end. You no longer need a COVID-19 test if you have symptoms, unless you:    - Are 55 or older and have not received a booster  - Have a high-risk medical condition  - Are immunocompromised  - Live in the same household or provide care and support to someone who is immunocompromised  - Are pregnant  - Are a healthcare worker    If you are a close contact with no symptoms, you no longer need a test unless you are a healthcare worker who is a household close contact.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220419100921/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

11th April 2022, Getting a booster dose    To get your first booster dose, you must be aged 12 or older.    12 to 15 year olds must attend their booster appointment with a parent or legal guardian. A parent or legal guardian will need to give consent for their child's vaccination.    Do not book an appointment for a second booster dose yet. These will be available soon for:    people over 65  people over 12 with a weak immune system  How long to wait before getting your first booster    After your first round of COVID-19 vaccination, you need to wait:    3 months (at least 90 days) if you are 16 or older  6 months (at least 182 days) if you are aged 12 to 15  You will not get your booster dose if the minimum interval has not passed on the day of your appointment.    If you had COVID-19 since you were vaccinated, you should get your booster dose at least:    3 months after your positive test result or when symptoms started if you are 16 or older  6 months after your positive test result or when symptoms started if you are aged 12 to 15  If you had an additional dose because you have a weak immune system, you can get your booster at least 3 months after your additional dose if you are 12 or older.    Vaccines:    Pfizer/BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine  Moderna/Spikevax COVID-19 vaccine  Novavax COVID-19 vaccine  Janssen COVID-19 vaccine  AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine (not currently available)    https://web.archive.org/web/20220412001307/https://covid19booster.healthservice.ie/hse-self-referral/?flow=booster

In order to enter a non-essential business, a green pass or super green pass is required.  A Super Green pass is mandatory to all workers 50+ and for some additional workers categories, irrespective of age. Such workplaces are virtually closed for those who are not vaccinated or recently recovered from Covid.  All other workers still need a Green Pass.  In all cases, masks and social distancing still are enforced at work.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220320203534/https://www.governo.it/sites/governo.it/files/documenti/documenti/Notizie-allegati/tabella_attivita_consentite.pdf

No Orange Zones from Feb 28th. All regions are now white except for Sardinia that is categorized as yellow. From March 1st almost all travel restrictions have been removed. The only restrictions still in place are to show a "green pass equivalent" certificate (so not a vaccine mandate).  Vaccinated people therefore just need to show their vaccination status, unvaccinated people need to show a negative test or proof or recent recovery from Covid. In case a proof of vaccination or recent recovery cannot be provided they will need to quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220324173209/https://www.salute.gov.it/portale/nuovocoronavirus/dettaglioContenutiNuovoCoronavirus.jsp?lingua=italiano&id=5411&area=nuovoCoronavirus&menu=vuoto  https://web.archive.org/web/20220325024444/https://www.esteri.it/it/ministero/normativaonline/focus-cittadini-italiani-in-rientro-dall-estero-e-cittadini-stranieri-in-italia/

Travelers without vaccination or valid PCR results will be denied entry.  Children under age 5 are exempt from testing or vaccination entry requirements." Quote: "The Ministry of Health provides free testing only for symptomatic patients. For those requiring a negative PCR test for travel, state laboratories in Bishkek and Osh can provide tests for a fee (approximately $20), depending on testing capacity. As of the 16th of February 2022, private and public events can be held and attended without Corona protection measures in place or COVID certificates required. There are no restrictions on private gatherings, though public gatherings with audience still have a cap of 1000 people. The same rules for entering Switzerland apply to entering Liechtenstein. You may only enter if you are fully vaccinated, with the final vaccine dose having been delivered in the past 270 days; if you are fully vaccinated, no negative test or entry form is required. If you are not fully vaccinated, and are not an EU, Swiss, or Liechtenstein national, or holder of a residency permit, you may not enter the country.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220305134613/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/de/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html & http://web.archive.org/web/20220305134849/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/liechtenstein/entry-requirements

Effective January 17, 2022, Moldova requires anyone entering the country present one of the following:  1) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose); 2) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; or 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date.  Any COVID-19 antibodies certificate or evidence of vaccination must be in Romanian, English, French, German, Italian, or Russian language.  Moldovan Border Police accept all types of vaccination with appropriate documentation.  Absent one of the documents listed above, a traveler will have to self-isolate for 14 days.  Self-isolation may be discontinued after 7 days if a COVID-19 PCR test or a rapid SARS-CoV-2 Ag test is performed, and the result is negative based on a confirmative document.  If you are subject to self-isolation and depart Moldova, you could be fined for violating self-isolation.  Anyone required to self-isolate should complete an online epidemiological card 3 days before arriving in Moldova.  Exceptions to the entry rules above are made for the following categories of persons if they do not show clinical signs of respiratory infection or fever:  1) children up to 12 years of age; 2) students up to 18 years age going to study or travel for activities related to completing/ organizing/conducting/ participating in international competitions; 3) persons travelling for health reasons, including accompanying persons with appropriate documentation; 4) passengers in transit (24 hours transiting Moldova), the transit itinerary to be established by the Border Police; 4) persons who are summoned by courts/law enforcement as well as their legal representatives with appropriate documentation; 5) holders of diplomatic, service, official and special passports, as well as holders of Laissez-Passer travel documents issued by the United Nations, including family members of diplomatic and consular missions, and international organizations/missions accredited to the Republic of Moldova.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220416101520/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

1/4/22    No change but from 28th March the requirement to isolate and wear masks has been abolished apart from medical institutes and pharmacies.    Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220317052425/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/aktualne-zasady-i-ograniczenia

No change    No change until 28th March 2022    You are not quarantined if your antigen or PCR test is negative  and you meet one of the following conditions :    you are vaccinated with the full vaccination course:  a vaccine that is authorized in the European Union or is included in the list of vaccine equivalents authorized for marketing in the territory of the Republic of Poland, kept by the National Institute of Public Health PZH - National Research Institute,  14 days have elapsed since the administration of the last dose of vaccination (counted from the day following the administration of the last dose),  vaccination is certified by the EU COVID Certificate or another document in Polish or English confirming the vaccination.  You have been infected with the SARS-CoV-2 virus (you are the so-called healer):  not later than 6 months before the day of crossing the PR border,  you have a document that confirms the presence of the disease, issued in Polish or English, including the EU COVID Certificate .  You are subject to other exemptions listed in Â§ 3 of the Regulation of the Council of Ministers of May 6, 2021 on the establishment of certain restrictions, orders and bans in connection with the occurrence of an epidemic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220308150404/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/przyjazd-do-polski-spoza-strefy-schengen

1/4/22  From March 28, the obligation to undergo quarantine after crossing the border will be abolished  From March 28, 2022, pursuant to the provisions of the Regulation of the Council of Ministers of March 25, 2022 on the establishment of certain restrictions, orders and bans in connection with an epidemic (Journal of Laws, item 673), all travel restrictions are lifted. The Republic of Poland, which means that there is no longer an obligation to:    - showing vaccination certificates when crossing the border,    - testing for SARS-CoV-2,    - taking the so-called incoming quarantine.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/granice-i-ruch-miedzynarodowy

No change    No change    Change in policy. Test are now available for anyone at a pharmacy without prior registration    How to get a coronavirus test at a pharmacy  No signups, no long waiting times and free of charge - now you can get tested at the pharmacy if you are concerned that you have the coronavirus. Check in which pharmacies near you can make it and on what terms!    In the pharmacy, you can do an antigen test:    without prior registration;  free;  unlimited - as many times as you need,  fast - the result after only a dozen or so minutes!  How to do it  Come to the pharmacy where the tests are performed - but be careful! Not every pharmacy participates in the program. Find out where the nearest pharmacy that runs the tests is .  The pharmacist will take a swab.  After a dozen or so minutes, you will receive the result and the pharmacist will enter it in the system.  You can also find information about the result on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .  Test results  If your score is:    negative - you will receive the EU COVID Certificate after the antigen test (valid for 48 hours),  positive - you will start home insulation .  Information on how long your isolation will last and certificates can be found on the Internet Patient Account and in the mojeIKP application .    Attention! Antigen tests are carried out in pharmacies. After a negative antigen test result, you can generate an EU COVID Certificate (UCC), but it will only be valid for 48 hours .    If you fall ill with the coronavirus and confirm the disease with the antigen test, you will not get the convalescent status and the EU COVID Certificate after 10 days!    Recover status confirmed by UCC can only be obtained after confirming the disease with  a PCR test performed at the collection point . Check how to sign up for a test at a download point .      https://web.archive.org/web/20220204154012/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zapisz-sie-na-test-na-koronawirusa

1/4/22  From April 1, 2022, the rules for ordering and performing coronavirus tests will change.  Your doctor will decide to refer you for a coronavirus test based on an assessment of your health, including symptoms that may indicate COVID-19. .  If a GP decides to test a patient with disturbing symptoms, it will be a rapid antigen test. The test result is known after a few or several minutes. The test will be free for the patient.  A PCR test may be ordered by your doctor prior to admission to hospital if deemed necessary. The PCR test will be used in the event of definitive confirmation or exclusion of whether the symptoms of respiratory tract infections with which the patient entered the hospital are caused by the coronavirus.  In the case of a positive SARS-CoV-2 test result, the doctor recommends self-isolation (sick leave) until symptoms disappear. Just like any infectious disease, such as the flu.  The length of the sick leave depends on the doctor (minimum 7 days recommended), depending on the patient's condition, risk factors for the severe course of the COVID-19 disease (e.g. lack of vaccination against COVID-19, advanced age, chronic diseases, e.g. diabetes) and high risk the occurrence of complications.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/zapisz-sie-na-test-na-koronawirusa

No change  Limited contact tracing in place.    I was in close contact with a person who tested positive. Should I report it somewhere?  If you are in close contact with a person infected with the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus (this person has obtained a confirmed, positive PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus infection), report this fact to the sanitary inspection. Use the online form: Application for quarantine or isolation by the Sanepid.    If you have questions about quarantine, please call the hotline to contact the sanitary inspection : +48 22 25 00 115. The  hotline is open 24 hours a day.    Important! If you know you have been in close contact with an infected or sick person, stay home - even if you have not yet decided to quarantine, and you are feeling well. Avoid contact with other people. You can infect them if you find out that you are infected. If this is not possible, use all required personal protective equipment.    Attention! If you have been vaccinated for COVID-19, you will not be placed in quarantine. The rule applies from December 28, 2020.    However, from December 15, family  members of people suffering from COVID19 must undergo a coronavirus test, regardless of the certificate they have.    https://archive.fo/wXmsk

1/4/22  I was in close contact with a person who tested positive. Should I report it somewhere?  Not. The so-called quarantine from contact.     Important! If you know that you have had close contact with an infected or sick person and you develop symptoms - take the test .    A test referral means an automatic quarantine that will end if you test negative. Quarantine does not apply to tests performed privately. A positive test result always requires isolation for 7 days.    Check the test result in the Internet Patient Account !    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/pytania-i-odpowiedzi

1/4/22  No change  How to get vaccinated?  The pass for vaccination is e-referral. Currently, children from 5 years of age can get vaccinated. There are a few basic rules to follow right before vaccination. Read on for details.    We want as many people as possible to receive the preparation against Covid-19 in the shortest possible time. It is in the interest of all of us - the vaccine offers a real chance of recovery.    E-referral    This is the document that entitles you to have the vaccine. In most cases, it is generated automatically for people who can sign up for a vaccination. Only in some cases do patients report to the doctor for this document. This happens when a given person does not have a PESEL number, or in the case of specific patients with the indicated diseases - they are informed about it.    The e-referral is valid for 90 days, but don't hesitate. If you have the opportunity, sign up for the vaccination now!    Registration for vaccination    Anyone who has an e-referral can sign up for a vaccination. There are several ways to do this:    call the helpline 989,  register online via e-Registration,  send an SMS saying SzczepimySie to the number 880 333 333,  mojeIKP - mobile application,  sign up directly at the vaccination point (preferably by phone),  use the drive-thru point .     Register for vaccination - find out the details    How to prepare for vaccinations *?    Get enough sleep before vaccination - sleep has a positive effect on the immune system.  Limit alcohol - a few days before vaccination, but also after taking the preparation, reduce the amount, and preferably do not consume alcohol at all.  Be physically active before vaccination - exercise improves your body's performance.  You do not need to fast before having the vaccine - eat all meals as normal on the day of vaccination.  Do not stop taking the medications you regularly take on your own - consult your doctor.  Carefully complete the pre-vaccination questionnaire - you will be asked to complete a medical questionnaire before taking the preparation. Don't withhold any information!  Wait after vaccination at the vaccination site of min . 15 minutes - it's for your safety.  Do not be afraid of NOP - it is short for undesirable vaccine reactions. They are mostly mild and rare. It may happen that after receiving the vaccine you will have, for example, redness at the injection site or a mild fever. These symptoms should disappear within 1-3 days. If you are more uncomfortable, you can take an anti-pyretic drug after vaccination.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/https://www.gov.pl/web/szczepimysie/jak-sie--zaszczepic

11.	The learning and teaching process in pre-school and daycare institutions shall take place according to the recommendations for pre-school institutions of NIPHK dated 20.01.2022.      12.	The learning and teaching process in all pre-university education institutions of all levels, as well as in daycare centres shall take place in accordance with the MEST Guidelines for the organization of the educational process in the conditions of the Covid-19 pandemic. The task forces of the educational institutions decide on the application of scenarios for the organization of the teaching process, depending on the situation in the institution and in the classrooms.    13.	The teaching process in public and private institutions of higher education, as well as in vocational and non-formal education institutions, can take place with physical presence provided that groups over 50 people are accommodated in no more than 50% of the space.     14.	Students must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2 in order to be allowed registration to the dormitory.    15.	Students in public and private university institutions must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the building of the institution.    16.	Staff in all public and private institutions of all levels of education, including preschool and daycare institutions, must possess any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2, in order to be allowed to enter the institution building.     17.	The highest administrative officer, or equivalent position, of each institution according to points 14, 15 and 16, is obliged by decision to appoint one or more responsible persons who will control the possession of any of the evidence mentioned in point 4.1 or 4.2.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315002518/https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/https:/msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

4.	All employees of public institutions, central and local public enterprises, private businesses, organizations, as well as other entities, must possess one of the following evidence, in order to be allowed to enter the work premises:  4.1	Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine against COVID-19;  4.2	Persons with medical evidence from a specialist in the relevant field that they have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination, must possess a negative RT-PCR test for COVID 19 not older than one week;    https://web.archive.org/web/20220315002518/https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/https:/msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

22.	Outdoor gatherings and cultural events are allowed. The organizer is obliged to ensure the observation of measures, including the maintenance of a physical distance of 1 meter between persons and the presentation of evidence recorded in points 19.1 to 19.4, except participants under the age of 12, as well as the wearing of masks.    https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

F. [Restriction of public and private gatherings]     19.	Unless otherwise specified in this Decision, indoor gatherings of up to 50% of capacities (workshops, meetings, seminars, trainings or other gatherings) are allowed. Except those under the age of 12, participants are obliged to possess any of the evidence mentioned in points 19.1 to 19.4 in order to be allowed to enter these premises, and the organizer is obliged to provide a physical distance of one (1) meter between persons and check the relevant evidence, such as:      19.1	Certificate of vaccination with at least two doses or one dose of Janssen vaccine against COVID-19;  19.2	Persons with medical evidence issued by the specialist doctor of the respective field verifying that they have contraindications and are exempt from vaccination must present the negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, which should not be older than 48 hours;  19.3	Single dose vaccination certificate, not older than one (1) month.  19.4	Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90 days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days).    20.	Meetings of the Assembly and Government are allowed regardless of the number of persons, respecting the wearing of masks and maintaining the physical distance of 1 (one) meter between persons.      21.	The Emergency Operational Centre of the Ministry of Health may issue a special permit, exceeding 50% of capacities, for events of special importance in the function of public interest.    22.	Outdoor gatherings and cultural events are allowed. The organizer is obliged to ensure the observation of measures, including the maintenance of a physical distance of 1 meter between persons and the presentation of evidence recorded in points 19.1 to 19.4, except participants under the age of 12, as well as the wearing of masks.    23.	Religious ceremonies and rites are allowed to carry out their activity up to 50% of the utilizing capacity, provided that they possess any of the evidence according to points 19.1 to 19.4 in order to be allowed to enter the indoor spaces, in accordance with the relevant instruction, except participants under the age of 12.    https://msh.rks-gov.net/sq/miratohen-masat-e-reja-kunder-covid-19-3/

Transportation Options  Are commercial flights operating? Yes  Reduced levels of commercial flights are available, but schedules change frequently so we recommend you check with the airline and/or travel agency for regular updates.  Is public transportation operating? Yes  https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/
https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

No more curfew     Movement Restrictions  Is a curfew in place? No.  For access to all public institutions, malls and dining inside restaurants, customers are obliged to possess evidence of vaccination, a negative PRC or rapid negative antigen test.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Public transport is allowed to operate.  Taxis are allowed to work.  Wearing a mask is mandatory when indoors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

Entry and Exit Requirements  Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? Yes  Is a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry? Varies (see below)  As of March 1, 2022, every person who enters Kosovo must produce one of the following:  Full vaccination certificate with two (2) doses (or a single-dose of Janssen vaccine) not exceeding more than 12 months after receiving the last dose;  Vaccination certificate with a single dose, together with a negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  Evidence that the person has recovered from COVID-19 in the last 90 days (positive RT-PCR test issued in the last 21â90 days);  Evidence that the person has received the third / booster dose;  Evidence of negative RT-PCR test for COVID-19, not older than 48 hours;  This requirement does not apply to children under the age of 12. Children from 12 to 16 years of age must have a negative RT-PCR test not older than 48 hours.    Airlines, transit points, and destination countries impose a patchwork of different testing requirements and airlines may refuse boarding for some passengers (including U.S. citizens and Kosovo residents). Airlines have the sole authority to decide who they allow to board their aircraft. Generally, pre-travel testing is recommended.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  The Pristina International Airport is open to travelers.  Check with the airlines, airports, and the U.S. Embassies located in your countries of transit to verify entry/exit requirements and be aware that they change frequently.    Quarantine Information  Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? Yes â self quarantine.  Citizens of the Republic of Kosovo, as well as persons with temporary or permanent resident permits, who enter the Republic of Kosovo and do not possess the evidence required above and seek to enter the country are obliged to respect home quarantine for a period of seven (7) days from the entry into the territory of the Republic of Kosovo.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220314235006/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/
No evidence of income support.
No evidence of debt/contract relief.
no change in policy.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211007101425/https://msh.rks-gov.net/en/

Testing available across Kosovo    COVID-19 Testing  Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Kosovo? Yes  There are PCR and rapid antigen tests available from several private labs in Pristina and major towns in Kosovo.  The main public hospital in Pristina, the University Clinical Center of Kosovo (UCCK), provides free travel testing without a referral although availability and scheduling depend on demand.  Are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Turn-around time for results from the private clinics vary from several hours to 24 hours and are available via email and hard copy. Results from UCCK are reportedly available within 24 hours, but it is best to check with them due to expected higher demand.  For information on limited humanitarian exemptions, please review the following page: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/ea/covid-testing-required-us-entry.html   If you are in Kosovo and have COVID-19 related questions, are symptomatic, or need information regarding testing, please call toll free 038 200 80 800, or dial 194.  The U.S. Embassy does not endorse or recommend any particular healthcare provider, but below is a list of clinics and hospitals who are providing tests. Please contact them directly for details on location, tests offered, and pricing:  Medical and Laboratory Services SHPK, +383 48 111 000 or +383 38 600 188  Prolab, +383 49 789 410  Olive Lab, +383 38 720 055, +383 49 520 056  UBT â Laboratori I Mikrobiologis e Klinike, + 383 46 500 777, +383 46 500 888  Avicena, +383 49 825 555  UCCK â University Clinical Center Kosovo (public hospital), +381 38 500 600    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101164843/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/
No evidence of contact tracing.

Wearing a mask covering the nose and mouth is mandatory in all cases when indoors.    All public and private institutions, as well as other entities are obliged to appoint an  employee who will monitor the implementation of the measure defined in point 11 and  the possession of evidence according to point 4.1 and 4.2.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211160214/https://mfa-ks.net/assets/cms/uploads/files/covid-19/THE%20GOVERNMENT%20DECISION%20ON%20PREVENTING%20AND%20FIGHTING%20COVID-19%20PANDEMICS_compressed.pdf

The vaccine is limited to individuals over the age of 12.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220211185746/https://xk.usembassy.gov/coronavirus/

Regions have been instructed to approve the work schedules of educational organizations for preschool and general education, and employers to transfer employees to remote work as much as possible.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220415234318/https://xn--80aesfpebagmfblc0a.xn--p1ai/news/20220126-1759.html    Russian government website can't be accessed due to military operation in Ukraine, but following measures have been put in place until april:    From October 25, 2021 to April 1, 2022, metropolitan enterprises must transfer to remote work:  at least 30 percent of the total number of employees;  all workers over 60 years of age and suffering from chronic diseases. An exception is only for employees whose presence in the workplace is critical to the functioning of the organization.    In addition, in organizations where possible, it is recommended to transfer the maximum number of people to a remote mode of work.    Russia's Labor Ministry has recommended that all enterprises send as many of their employees to remote work as possible due to the surge in Covid-19 cases.    Previous archives:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220218140404/https://tass.ru/obschestvo/13583061    As there are no signs on the main information platforms that the rules have changed, code remains in place.

Government website cannot be accessed due to military operation in Ukraine, but UK government travel advice page (https://web.archive.org/web/20220415233119/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/russia/coronavirus) suggests no change.    In Moscow, since November 8, 2021, it is mandatory to use a  QR code and a mask at concerts, entertainment, cultural, entertainment, sports and other events with the simultaneous presence of more than 500 people. Event organizers with less than 500 attendees are encouraged to make similar decisions.  Previous archive:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220220025511/https://www.mos.ru/city/projects/measures/    QR codes may be required to access venues such as museums, theatres, stadiums, shopping centres or restaurants. QR codes are typically issued to those either vaccinated with a Russian vaccine, recently recovered from COVID-19 or with a recent negative PCR test. Requirements and procedures for obtaining QR codes vary depending on the region. Foreign nationals may not be required to have a QR code if they present a documentary proof of full vaccination by a Russian vaccine.

On 18 March 2020 the Russian government introduced restrictions on entry into the whole country for almost all foreign citizens. On 30 March 2020, temporary restrictions on entry and exit via Russiaâs land borders were enforced. The duration of these remains unspecified.    These restrictions were eased on 16 April 2021 for nationals and permanent residents of certain countries including the UK. They may now travel to Russia by air via authorised 3rd countries. The full list is subject to change and currently includes Albania; Andorra; Argentina; Armenia; Austria; Azerbaijan; Bahamas; Bahrain; Bangladesh; Belgium; Brazil; Bulgaria; China; Columbia; Costa Rica; Croatia; Cuba; Cyprus; Czech Republic; Denmark; Djibouti; Dominican Republic; Egypt; Ethiopia; Finland; France; Germany; Greece; Hungary; Iceland; India; Indonesia; Iran; Iraq; Italy; Japan; Jordan; Kazakhstan; Kenya; Kuwait; Kyrgyzstan; Lebanon; Lichtenstein; Luxemburg; Maldives; Malta; Mauritius; Mexico; Moldova; Mongolia; Morocco; Netherlands; New Zealand; North Macedonia; Norway; Oman; Peru; Portugal; Qatar; Republic of Ireland; Republic of Korea; Republic of Seychelles; Saudi Arabia; Serbia; Singapore; Slovakia; Slovenia; Spain; Sri-Lanka; Sweden; Switzerland; Syria; Tajikistan; Thailand; Tunisia; Turkey; Turkmenistan; United States of America; Uzbekistan; Vietnam; Venezuela; United Arab Emirates; United Kingdom.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220405071920/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/russia/entry-requirements    From 9 April 2022 the Russian government lifted some COVID-related restrictions on entry and exit via Russiaâs air borders for 52 countries. However, non-Russian nationals must still produce a negative PCR test taken within 48 hours of their arrival in Russia. You should check with your airlines before you travel to keep up to date with the latest requirements.    Temporary COVID-related restrictions on entry and exit via Russiaâs land borders still remain in force for most countries.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220415232618/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/russia/entry-requirements

Any citizen of the Russian Federation over the age of 18 can register for the vaccination. The following categories of citizens are subject to priority vaccination: - persons over 60 years of age; - social workers and others who work with large numbers of people; - people with chronic diseases. 8 different vaccines are used (Sputnik V, EpiVacCorona, Sputnik Light, EpiVakKorona-N, Sputnik M, Kovivak, Convasel, Ad5-nCoV).    https://web.archive.org/web/20220416000015/https://xn--80aaezjt5d.xn--80aesfpebagmfblc0a.xn--p1ai/

In some areas, there are stay at home requirements for unvaccined people above the age of 60. However, multiple regions have been lifting this restrictions in the last couple of weeks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220416001221/https://xn--80aesfpebagmfblc0a.xn--p1ai/news/?tags=18&page=1

The Authorities of the Republic of San Marino issued Decree-Law no. 3 of 14 January 2022 - Strengthening of provisions to avoid the spread of the COVID-19 virus. The provisions of the aforementioned Decree-Law, ratified by Decree-Law no. 6 of 21 January 2022, unless otherwise provided for, shall apply until the end of the health emergency, which is currently extended until 30 April 2022.         Entry into the Republic of San Marino, for those coming from countries other than Italy and the Vatican City, or who have stayed outside these two countries in the previous 14 days, is permitted on presentation of the following documents:         A certificate of vaccination against SARS-CoV-2* or a certificate of recovery from SARS-CoV-2 within the previous six months. This certificate may be in paper or digital form;  Or    A negative coronavirus test certificate following a molecular or antigenic swab taken no later than 48 hours before entry and in any case in accordance with the health protocols in force in the Republic of San Marino. Any molecular swab taken within 48 hours prior to entry into the territory of the Italian Republic is considered valid for those who do not fall within the cases referred to in letter a) above.        Children under ten years of age are exempt from submitting the certificates referred to in letters a) and b).    https://web.archive.org/web/2021*/https://www.esteri.sm/pub2/EsteriSM/en/Covid/Covid.html

Children under ten years of age are exempt from submitting the certificates referred to in letters a) and b).    https://web.archive.org/web/2021*/https://www.esteri.sm/pub2/EsteriSM/en/Covid/Covid.html

Schools are fully open.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220406140924/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse & http://web.archive.org/web/20220406141347/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Workers in healthcare and social protection sectors (including hospitals, social care institutions and prisons) are required to comply by the "RVT - recovered, vaccinated, or tested" rule to enter workplaces. This has been relaxed, with previously more places of work having to abide by this rule.  - Recovery must be proved via a positive PCR result in the last 180 days  - An individual is considered vaccinated from the day of their vaccination, and onwards.  - Tests can either be in the form of a rapid antigen test conducted in the last 48 hours or a PCR test conducted in the last 72 hours.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220406141347/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

Following easing of almost all restrictions on the 22nd of February, there is no longer any restrictions on public events taking place, though masks are recommended at outdoor events where 1.5m social distancing is not possible.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170902/https://www.total-slovenia-news.com/politics/9624-slovenia-ends-almost-all-covid-restrictions-except-masks

There is no longer a cap on the number of people allowed to gather, either in public or private  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309170902/https://www.total-slovenia-news.com/politics/9624-slovenia-ends-almost-all-covid-restrictions-except-masks

Public transport is running as usual, with a mask mandate for all passengers over 6 years old and all drivers.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220406141347/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

People who are ill are told to stay home. People who have come into close contact with a positive case are no longer required to quarantine.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220406141904/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

There are no restrictions on internal movement.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220406141347/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

All travellers arriving in Slovenia will no longer be required to present proof of vaccination or a negative COVID-19 test. All travellers arriving in Slovenia must continue to complete the Digital Passenger Locator Form 24 hours before arrival, if entering via an airport or a ferry terminal. The form is not required if entering overland at a border crossing.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309171748/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/slovenia/entry-requirements & http://web.archive.org/web/20220309171842/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/border-crossing/

No policy change.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309174611/https://www.gov.si/teme/koronavirus-sars-cov-2/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220309174715/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No policy change.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309174611/https://www.gov.si/teme/koronavirus-sars-cov-2/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220309174715/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
Up to date and detailed information is available via the government website.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163718/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

Free testing with a rapid antigen test and a rapid antigen test for self-testing is abolished. The government budget will only pay for testing with a rapid antigen test for activities where this is still required. Such activities include:  - Users of hospital and other healthcare services   - Persons who wish to discontinue their self-isolation between days 7 and 10 after testing positive  - Persons with proof of a positive rapid-antigen self-test result   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163253/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163718/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

A person who has tested positive in a coronavirus test must inform all those with whom he or she has been in close contact.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220325163718/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/

Surgical mask II or IIR or a FFP2 or a FFP3 mask are mandatory in all closed public spaces and on public transport. Protective masks are recommended in open public spaces or outside if a distance of at least 1.5 metres is not possible to maintain.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220406141347/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-covid-19-infections/

AstraZeneca, Moderna, and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines are available for those age 12 and older. The Comirnaty 10 Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine is available to all children aged 5-11; this is especially recommended in children who are immunocompromised.  Vaccination is free of charge and is provided to all those who have permanent or temporary residence in the Republic of Slovenia, regardless of whether they are insured.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20220309181259/https://www.gov.si/teme/koronavirus-sars-cov-2/cepljenje-proti-covid-19/ & http://web.archive.org/web/20220406143814/https://www.nijz.si/sl/cepljenje-proti-covid-19-za-strokovno-javnost

1st April 2022 onwards, the remaining official recommendations will be removed or adapted to the rate of transmission, the burden on health care services, and vaccination rates at that time. After that, the vaccination recommendation will remain in place, along with specific recommendations for health service and care environments.    The new measures include the removal of participants limits in public gatherings and events, abolishing maximum group sizes in eating and drinking establishments, shopping centers, private gatherings and tournaments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319142922/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/travelling-to-sweden-entry-rules-restrictions-explained/

Non-fully vaccinated travellers, e.g., unaccompanied minors, the partly vaccinated, or travellers with medical exemptions, are not exempted. The exemption is entirely connected to the vaccine certificate, not of country of residence or citizenship,    The list of approved countries in Sweden consists of:    Albania  Andorra  Armenia  Cabo Verde  El Salvador  Faroe Islands  Georgia  Israel  Lebanon  Morocco  Moldova  Monaco  Montenegro  New Zeeland  North Macedonia  Panama  San Marino  Serbia  Singapore  Switzerland  Taiwan  Thailand  Togo  Tunisia  Turkey  Ukraine  United Arab Emirates  The UK + Guernsey, Isle of Man and Jersey  Uruguay  USA  Vatican    The new measures include the removal of participants limits in public gatherings and events, abolishing maximum group sizes in eating and drinking establishments, shopping centers, private gatherings and tournaments.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319142922/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/travelling-to-sweden-entry-rules-restrictions-explained/

Starting April 1, Travelers to Sweden no longer need to show proof of vaccination or prearrival testing.     This means that everyone, regardless of their vaccination or recovery status, can now enter Sweden for all kinds of purposes without being required to follow additional entry rules.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220405082118/https://www.afar.com/magazine/sweden-drops-all-covid-related-travel-restrictions

COVID-19 vaccines if you live in Tajikistan  We will update this page when the Government of Tajikistan announces new information on the national vaccination programme. You can sign up to get email notifications when this page is updated.    The Tajikistan national vaccination programme started in March 2021 and is using the AstraZeneca, Janssen (Johnson and Johnson) and Sinovac vaccines. The Tajikistan authorities have stated that British nationals resident in Tajikistan are eligible for vaccination if they choose to join the programme. Further information is available on the Ministry of Health website    Find out more, including about vaccines that are authorised in the UK or approved by the World Health Organisation, on the COVID-19 vaccines if you live abroad.    If youâre a British national living in Tajikistan, you should seek medical advice from your local healthcare provider. Information about COVID-19 vaccines used in the national programme where you live, including regulatory status, should be available from local authorities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220411094017/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/tajikistan/coronavirus    Which vaccines are available in TAJIKISTAN?    The U.S. Embassy in Dushanbe is aware that Pfizer, Moderna, AstraZeneca, Sputnik V and Sinovac-CoronaVac COVID-19 vaccines are available at Prospekt Medical Clinic (48-702-44-00), subject to availability.  Please contact the clinic directly for information about cost and availability.  The quality of Tajikistanâs medical infrastructure is significantly below Western standards, with shortages of basic medical supplies, including disposable needles, anesthetics, and antibiotics.  Due to extremely limited vaccine availability, we strongly recommend that travelers complete their COVID-19 vaccination before traveling to Tajikistan.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220409143707/https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

COVID-19 vaccines if you live in Tajikistan  We will update this page when the Government of Tajikistan announces new information on the national vaccination programme. You can sign up to get email notifications when this page is updated.    The Tajikistan national vaccination programme started in March 2021 and is using the AstraZeneca, Janssen (Johnson and Johnson) and Sinovac vaccines. The Tajikistan authorities have stated that British nationals resident in Tajikistan are eligible for vaccination if they choose to join the programme. Further information is available on the Ministry of Health website    Find out more, including about vaccines that are authorised in the UK or approved by the World Health Organisation, on the COVID-19 vaccines if you live abroad. Travel in Tajikistan  Currently, there are no local restrictions or localised lockdowns in place but you should monitor updates by the Tajikistan Government and should comply with any restrictions, health or screening measures introduced by the authorities.    Breaches of regulations can result in fines or eventually imprisonment.    Accommodation  Hotels and private rentals are generally open. Travellers should check with the accommodation provider to confirm availability and regulations.    Public places and services  Public places and services in Tajikistan are open. Local regulations, including wearing of face masks if applicable, should be observed at all times.    https://archive.ph/OsDTz

A PCR test is required for individuals over the age of 12 years old who are unable to show proof of vaccination.  Are health screening procedures in place at airports and other ports of entry? Yes  COVID-19 control measures for air, land, and sea travel continue. Passengers arriving in Turkey?will be required to complete an information form and will be checked for symptoms. Passengers may be subject to a PCR test by means of the method of sampling at points of arrival in Turkey. Within this scope, these passengers shall be allowed to proceed to their final destination after their test samples are taken. If their test results are positive, they shall be taken under treatment in accordance with the COVID-19 Guidelines of the Ministry of Health. The passengers with positive test results and persons having been in close contact with such passengers shall be taken under quarantine for a period of 7 days at the addresses they have determined, and if the results of the PCR tests to be taken at the end of the 5th day are negative, the quarantine shall be ended. The quarantines of these people who are identified to have Delta variant shall be ended upon submitting a negative PCR test result at the end of the 7th day.  Passengers must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken at most 72 hours before arrival, if arriving from or they have been in Afghanistan, South Africa, Botswana, Mozambique, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Brazil, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, India and Pakistan in the last 14 days.    This does not apply to passengers younger than 12 years.  Passengers arriving from Egypt and Iran must have a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken at most 72 hours before arrival.  This does not apply to passengers younger than 12 years.  Effective January 10, 2022, passengers arriving from a country other than above countries do not need to submit negative PCR /rapid antigen test if;   passengers younger than 12 years;  passengers with a COVID-19 vaccination certificate showing that they were fully vaccinated at least 14 days before arrival;  passengers with a COVID-19 recovery certificate issued at most 6 months before arrival;  merchant seamen.  Passengers arriving into Turkey may be subject to a random PCR test at their final destination in Turkey.    A completed âTraveler Entry Formâ must be presented at check-in and upon arrival. The form can be obtained at http://register.health.gov.tr.    Passengers could be subject to self-isolation for up to 14 days.    This does not apply to passenger with a COVID-19 vaccination certificate showing that they were fully vaccinated at least 14 days before arrival.

In early 2021, after disbursing the funds through the budget, the government closed the Anti-Crisis Fund. The governmentâs 2021 budget includes higher expenditures on healthcare and social assistance as well as policy lending to support the economy, primarily through the Fund for Reconstruction and Development.      http://web.archive.org/web/20220417173221/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The central bank suggested banks defer loan repayments of firms in sectors affected by COVID-19. Subsequently, state-owned banks extended deadlines for loan repayments for affected sectors, including for the national air carrier. The central bank reduced its policy rate by 200 basis points in 2020. The policy rate was reduced from 16 to 15 percent on April 15, and from 15 to 14 percent on September 8. While the central bank has not changed requirements for regulatory capital or liquidity, it delayed phasing in tighter liquidity regulations and restricted banksâ dividend distributions. In October 2020, the authorities recommended that banks consider further deferral of loan repayments on a case by case basis.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220417173221/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
